assignments.utilization_method: Place the empty paper cup upright on the table. Aim the strike at the reinforced rim. The stiff rolled lip offers an initial crisp resistance; immediately after impact the thin paper wall buckles and collapses, letting the bottle drive downward with almost no opposition. The instantaneous shift from firm to soft collapse mirrors the feeling of bursting through a watermelon’s outer rind.

physical_object.name: rectangular cracker in a transparent wrapper with red accents

assignments.utilization_method: Lay the wrapped cracker flat on the table. Drive the bottle straight down through the centre line. The brittle cracker snaps with an audible crack and the wrapper deflects, giving a firm initial hit followed by a distinct break that convincingly imitates the axe clearing through a log.

Grip the tiny knob on top between thumb and forefinger as the mug handle. The dense 500 g mass beneath your fingers immediately produces strong forward-pulling inertia, closely matching the virtual mug’s heavy, forward-weighted feel when you lift or tilt it.

Extend the telescoping pole partway and grasp the rubberized handle at the base. The distant phone clamp forms a smaller, slightly heavier end, emulating a head-heavy tool, while the cylindrical grip and full length allow authentic two-handed axe swings.

physical_object.name: black Tesla-branded insulated water bottle with silver lid

assignments.utilization_method: Grasp the bottle 2–3 cm above its base so that most of the mass (filled liquid + metal cap) sits forward of the hand. This creates a mild head-heavy feel and the cylindrical body gives the fingers a firm, full power-grip similar to a hammer handle. Swing the wrist in short arcs; the inertia of the bottle reproduces the weighted head sensation.

physical_object.name: gray and white camouflage-patterned game controller

assignments.utilization_method: Envelop one of the controller’s handgrips in a power grip so that the opposite, heavier wing extends forward like a hooked blade. Swinging the controller yields an off-center mass that simulates the sickle’s forward-weighted feel.
